content: unworked this is a bit odd-looking right now but what you ve done is set yourself up to gradually work those unworked stitches back in as you go back and forth in the center and in such a way that the fabric will end up curving notice how there s a gap on each side between the worked and unworked stitches on each row you will make a ssk or a p2tog that will combine a worked and an unworked stitch together closing up that gap by the time you re done there will be no gaps at all have faith it will work c turn the work so the right side outside is facing you ignore the unworked stitches to the right of the last worked stitch with yarn in back slip 1 as if to purl knit to 1 stitch before the gap ssk using the last worked stitch as the first slip and the first unworked stitch as the second slip knit 1 d turn the work so the wrong side inside is facing you ignore the unworked stitches to the right of the last worked stitch slip 1 as if to purl purl to 1 stitch before the gap p2tog including the last worked stitch and the first unworked stitch purl 1 repeat c and d until you have worked all the stitches ending with d you should have 22 stitches left gusset the next step is to transition back from working flat back and forth in row to working in the round to do that we need to reestablish our cylinder we have the top half of the sock that s been resting while we ve worked on the heel and we have the turn of the heel which is the very bottom part remember the 15 bigger stitches on the sides of the rectangle just below the leg of the sock we ll make the sides of our new cylinder by picking up stitches creating new loops in those larger slipped stitches along the sides of the heel flap knit across the heel then pick up and knit 15 stitches along the right side of the heel flap these stitches are going into those larger-looking stitches pictured above on page 2 © 2025 kiersten harrod all rights reserved go to www kierstenj com for more resources to help you be a better knitter page 4 of 7 many people do this by inserting their right needle beneath the legs of the v of the slipped stitch wrapping their working yarn around the needle as they do when making a knit stitch and using the right needle to bring that loop under the legs others use their left needle to assist in making a space under the slipped stitch or to more closely replicate the feel of a
